newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: PRESS DIGEST - Czech Republic - Oct 11.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Czech Republic - Oct 11.

text.p: PRAVO - Unemployment increased to 3.2 percent in September, up from 3.1 percent in August according to the Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs. The lowest unemployment is in Prague (0.4 percent) while the highest is in the Most region (9.1 percent).

- Textbook publishers are unhappy with the Ministry of Education for allowing Fortuna to publish the Zakladni Skola programme without a public tender for the contract. Bohumir Sumsky, the director of the elementary school department of the ministry, stated the ministry did not request anything from Fortuna, they offered it themselves. He admitted it was "probably a mistake."

- The discussion on the Social Democrats proposal regarding church property turned into a polemic on whether the church has a right to any property or not. CSSD proposed the government should not give any property back to the church until a law on state property has been brought before parliament.

- The increase in fuel prices is due to the increasing price of petroleum on world markets and not the entrance of Agip, Conoco and Shell to Ceska Rafinerska, according to the general manager of Ceska Rafinerska, Ivan Ottis. Ceska Refinerska is the only producer of petrol and diesel in the Czech Republic.
- The managerial company Portum became the owner of the Expandia financial holding company, whose subjects have assets totalling 10 billion crowns.

- Industrial production in August increased by 5.8 percent compared to the same month a year earlier according to the Czech Statistics Office. This is 0.8 percent more than preliminary information indicated.
- Ceskoslovenska Obchodni Banka has no doubts that Slovakia will pay the debt of 11 billion owed to the bank according to the bank's press spokesman Milan Tomanek.

- The number of primary telephone stations increased by 296,000 by the end of the first half of 1996 as compared with June, 1995, which is an increase of 13 percent. There are still 650,000 outstanding requests for telephones, however, according to the Czech Statistics Office.
- Centrotex, which already controls majority stakes in four Czech textile companies, also wants to obtain Perla Usti nad Orlici and Jitex Pisek.
- Bohemia Sekt a.s. posted a net profit of 56 million crowns on a turnover of 583 million crowns in 1995, a yearly increase of 19 percent for profit and 29 percent for turnover.

HOSPODARSKE NOVINY - The privatisation of Czech banks in which the state has a majority stake, meaning Komercni Banka, Ceska Sporitelna, IPB and CSOB, will be discussed by the government in the near future according to Finance Minister, Ivan Kocarnik. "We must do something with bank privatisation, and we must do it quickly," he stated.
- Prague saw a 33 percent increase of visitors to the city in the first half of this year.
